Try to assess your child’s requirements, his personality, and strengths. Ask Some Question yourself - Does my child need a more structured environment? Does my child have any special learning needs? Does my child need more individual attention? Does my child like to learn in groups or work alone? These question helps to choose the right school for your Child. Visit Potential Schools Once you have shortlisted your options, it’s time to visit all the potential schools. The first point of contact with any school is generally the admissions department. Ask the person in charge to give you a brief tour of the schools and the classrooms so you can acquaint yourself with the environment. During your visit, try to observe the teachers and students. Have a look inside the classrooms to check out if the students look engaged. Meet other parents and talk to them about their child. See if they look open and welcoming. This is such a common and such a hard question. You want to do well for your child, you also want him/her to be happy. I have long maintained that it is possible for some children to get a third-rate education at a first-rate school or university. The reverse is also possible. Go to the school where you like the atmosphere, ethos, the head/principal. The program has to be good, and the school should show signs of good maintenance and management - but it doesn’t have to be swimming in money. How much litter and graffiti is there? What does the artwork look like? The written work? If you can, visit the school when it’s in session (with your child). That will tell you what you need to know. You will see if the discipline is good, if there is an atmosphere for learning. Find out about extra-curricular activities and sports, and enrichment programmes. At my secondary school, we do a comprehensive survey of visiting parents looking for a school for their 11 year-olds. Number one on the list of what they are looking for is atmosphere/ethos. Exam results is consistently in eighth (EIGHTH!) place. That will change as their children get near their exams, but at 11, they want them to be safe and happy. Good luck!
